vania. was informed of some choice land, not
included in his former purchase of the lndi-
ans. He caused inquiry to be made of the
chiefs whether they would sell it to him.
They replied that they did not wish to part
,,;,h that land. as the bones of their fathers
and their mothers were lying there; but still.
to please their father Onas they would sell
some oft. For certain quantity of Eng
lish goods they agreed to sell him as much
land as one Of his young men coulo wax a
round in day; beginning at the grea' rly-
er Coaquanoc," now Kens'ngton, "ana END

SeOHN BANCROFT, having removed from

ry, Delaware Co. Pa, takes this means to In

custom; and that he hopes by strict attention and
nunctualjty,I 10 merit a continuance of pub
lie patronage He also takes this opportunity
to inform those to whose favor he was indebted
for work in this line, while at Brandywine Bridge,
that all wool left rhim to card, at John Torbers
Store, or at the soap Factory of Brainton 8. Ban
croft, wilmington, or at VIM. 'Cauley's Store,

cry week, and, being carded, will be punctually
retuned the week following; hoping, by the a.
hove arrangement, and punctualy in the return
and GOOD performance of the work cenGded to
him, they may be induced to continue their fa-

In consequence Of the increased demand for
the American Quarterly Review, the publishers
have found it necessary to put to press second
edition of the first number OF that work, allho'
there were two thousand issued at first.


The amount of donations to the Philadelphia
Greek fund is Sl6,670.


The last cotton crop Of Tennessee is expected
TO fall short of tDo millions and h0t dollars, or
even three millions. Trade is very brisk at Nash
Vile.

says he killed brace of partridges in the
Garden of Eden.-Quere, were they not
birds ofParad,se?

ing one evening with guineas as spur -rowels,
remarked, "that in addition to his other
property. he had got f.vo saineas 10 boot"

schooner Grampus, arrived at Pensacola on

tativc in Congress from Berkshire District,
Mass.

ry Of the United States, at Madrid, and which

"Amerca, or General Survey of the Polite
al Situation of the several Powers of the West

In discussion which took place in the n
York Legislature, on the Chemung Canal
in 1916, the canal debt will have been paid
and leave an excess Of four million to the
State.
CIEANTMGS.

These harbingers of spring, after having
without any outfit, performed the duties OF
their mission to South America, have sent
on special messengers to announce their re,
turn and to take possession OF their ola
quarters. The whole CROPS may be
soon expected. as their cDanf eon'iers never
precede the main body more than week.
The usual time of their return from their
southern residence, is about the 2oth OF
March, and when they come sooner II is
to announce great fruit year. Our Hor-
ticultural friends are therefore ADVISED to
prepare their brandy casks and cordial Jugs
in due time, as there can be no doubt o,
their having use for all they ever had' ano
more besides-JTar. Reh.
ADVENT OF THE. MARTINS.

1MPROMPTU,
To young Lady on presenting me cake IN form


Of a heart.
And Rachel will you give your heart
To sad misfortune's wayward child
And with boon so precious part,
For one by sad a0liction spoiPdf
Say, shall take in my fond care,
The dearest pledge to mortals given,
And with affection place il near
Thy hapless friends, by sorrow riven'
Then give it hcre-yes, give it here,
And will ever fondly cherish,
With warm affection, one so dear,
Till every pulse of life shall perish.
And then thought how flecting time,
Would sudden pa its sceptre Ger,
And doom me to distant cline,
Where may never see thee more:
but yet, something told my heart,
'Twould cherish thee tho far apart.


BRANDYWINE MINSTREL.
For the Wiimingtonian.

ATTENTION!

CO." now Bristol. The bargain being made,
a young Englishman, much accustomed to
travelling, was selected to lay cut the land.
His walk both astonished and mortified the
Indians. When they came for their pay,
the Governor perceived dissatifaction in
their countenances and asked the cause.


They replied that the young man had
cheated them.
"Ah, how can that be-" said William
Penn. "Was it not of your own choosing
that the ground should be measured in this
way!'


"True," replied the Indians. "but the
white brother made too big walk"
Some of Penn's commissioners became
one-that the Indians ought to stand to it,
and if not, they ought to be compelled.


"Comhelled" replied the Governor.


show are they to be compelled DON'T you


see that this points to murder I" Then turn
ing to the Indians with smiling counte-
nance he said to thcm-"Well, if you have


given too much land for the goods first a


egreed on, how much more will do?''


With this the Indians appeared much


pleased, and mentioned the number of yards


of cloth, and FISH hooks, with which they


would be satisfied. These wese given, then


the Indians shook hands with the Governor,


and retired smiling and happy. The Indl-


ans being gone, William Penn looked around


on his friends, and lifting his hands and eyes
exclaimed-"O what sweet and cheap
thing is charity Mention was made just
now Of comtciling these poor creatures to
;, stick to their bargain; that is in plain Eng
lish to fight and kill them-and all about a


little piece Of land J"


y This account is the substance of the story
:; as related in Wecms' life of William Penn
1t is so characteristic OF that remarkable
4 man, that there can be little doubt of its gen.
uincncss and authenticity.


). How happy it would have been for The
Z, early settlers of all the American colonies
n and how happy for the numerous tribes o
n aborigines, had all our ancestors possessed
d the pacific policy Of Governor Penn How


much anxiety and distress. and how man,


hundreds of lives would have been saved
,s And who can help wishing that the peopl
IS of Georgia, at the present time, might b.
e blessed with william Penn, fer their Gov
e crnor! In that case, how easy it would b
q to settle all difficulties with the Greek Indi
y ans.-Friend Of Peace.

Commercial AQvertlsef,) WIKI VAC Si6hs Va
letters dated on the goth. which announce
the severe and dangerous situation OF Lord
Liverpool. On the 18th, His Lordship had
a severe attack Of the palsy and apoplexy,
from which he was not expected to recover.
Mr.. Canning continued i'll at the last advices
from London.-The illness Of those distin-
guished and leading men, had caused great
panic in the Stock Market, and the funds
had fallen two per cent. One of the let
ters says, "You know the great corn question
was to be brought forward on the 26th,-
what will be done now we cannot say; but
the subject will most probably be further
postponed until some change takes place in
the situation of Lord Liverpool and Mr..
Canning"


The ship Chancellor, Captain Baker, with
provisions for the Greeks, sailed from New
York on Monday morning last, having been
thoroughly repaired. Her cargo was not
damaged in the gale which caused her to
return to poEs.

Destruction of Insects.-As the season OF
vegetation approaches, remark upon the
application of tobacco water in the destruc-
tion OF insects may not be amiss. In the pro-
cess Of preparing tobacco for use, liquid is
finally expressed from it, which is very
cheap, and highly destructive to animal life
This mixed with three to five parts water,
is found to be an eilectual remedy, for the
aphies, caterpillars, and similar insects
which infcst fruit trees.

ANFCDOTE OF COLUMBUS.


Deter MARTYR. In his very curious account OF
coumbus' vevages, tells us that on his land-
,,g an the Island Of Jamaica. he immediate
im"peaus.d mp mass to be said on account ot the
.s,fe landing of himself and followers, and
.,., during the performance of that sacred !
my,,ery, an old Carib, eighty years OF age.
a,tended by several Of his countrymen, OBJ
.crved the service with great attention. At |
,.r;t was over, the old man approached Co.
lmbus with basket OF fruit IN his hand,
which he in very courteous manner pre-
sented to him, and by means OF au interpre-
ter thus addressed him:
ave have been told, that you have in a
verv powerful and surprising manner ran o.
YER several countries which were before un-
knowa to you,' and that you have filled the
inhabitants with fear and amazement.-----
Wherefore exhort and desire you to re-
member that the souls Of men when they arc
separated from :helr bodies have ivy" pas
sages; the one hurrd and dark, prepared
for those who have been troublesome and
inimicsl to the human race; the other,
rlcasant and delightful one, appointed for





n the peace and quiet of mankind. There
fore YOU will do no hurt to any one, II you
b-ar in mind that you are mortal and that
every one will be rewarded or punished in
, future state, according to his actions in the
present one"
Columbus. by the interpreter, answered
,heold man. "that what he had told respect
fnr the passage Of the souls after the death
Of the body, had been long known to him
and his countrymen, and that he was much
SURPRISED those notions prevailed among
them. who seemed to be living in quite a
state a. nature. That he (Columbus) and
his followers, were sent by the King and
Oueen ofSpain, to discover all those parts
If the world that had hitherto been unknown,
that they might civilize the cannibals and
other wild men that lived in those countries,
and intlict proper punishment upon them,
and that they might defend and honor those
nersons who were virtuous and innocent :
and that therefore neither himself nor any
other Carb, who had no intention Of hurting
them. had the least reason to fear any vio-
lcncc and that they would avepge any inju-
~ that should be offered to him or any other
worthy persons of the island, by any Of their
neighbors."


The old man was 50 pleased with the
sn.ech and the manner of Columbus, that
though he was extremely old, he offered tc
follow Columbus, and would have done so
had not his wife and children prevented him
The old man appeared much surprised tl
understand how man of Columbus dignlt!
and appearance should be under the controu
of another person, and became much moro
astonished when the interpreter explained
20 him the honor, the pomp and wealth. o
sc nnI IA.
extent Of the country and the greatness ant
beauty of the things over which they reign
ed. lie became pensive, melancholy, and il
Aood Of tears asked the interpreter repeat
cdly. whether it were the heavens or eartl
which had produced men so superior 4
themselves as Columbus and his followers


The Floridds.--Varous accounts hav
been Given fthe Floridas. The first dis
ceyerers of the coast described it as terres
tial paradise; and it still retains tho name c
the iscountry of flowers" which these marin
ers first gave it, in their surprize at the bea
" of its aspect when they landed. MI
Flint in his RecoliectionS, describes 1t as pri


cipally composed of pine barrens, intersect
ed by unwholesome meadows on the bank
of the rivers A traveller lately returnc
from Florida says it is the most fertile cour
try he ever found, the lands producing .fo'
~ bushels Of frogs TO the gore, and alf'gd
tors enough TO fence them.


Joe Daviess County.-This is without cs
ceptiOn the most ludicrous honor ever cor
ferred by a legislature upon the memory
any individual; but true it is that the legl


lature of Illinois a, its last session passed a
act establishing Jo Daviess County, and o


dered "that 1--WE quote the language OF It


act) to perpetuate the memory OF Col. j


seph Hamilton Daviess, who fell in the ba


tie of Tippecanoe, gallantly charging upc


the enemy at the head Of his corps, the sa


county shall be called 10 Daviess." TT


legislature that passed such a law must il


deed have been Of most primitive order.

there have been alarming reports in Lircu

The ship Maria, arrived at New York, on
Friday night last, from Canton, sailed 2oth
December. We learn by her, that III con-
sequence of the low prices of teas in China
and the bad accounts OF the American marx
ct being received there. the Hong mer-
chants had recommended their friends TO
sell their Teas in the interior, rather than
forward them to Canton; the consequence
has oeen the supply there was so very small
that the ships have all been detained much
longer than usual Before the Maria sailed,
subsequent accounts had been received IRON
this country, Of good prospects for the spring
trade, which caused very material advance


in the prices of Teas.--OlorainS ChFon'efe

Snare for taking The Red Deer IL the He
brides.--A wall or rampant OF stone was e
rec.ed along the side of a mountain, thanking
a considerable part near its basis; at either
extremity pit was formed concealed by a
circumference Of the same stones which
formed the rampant. In this pit the hunter
stationed himself with his gun. A number
of people were then employed to alarm the
deer, who instantly taking to the mountain
and meeting with the wall, ran along the
side of it till they came TO the pit in which
the sentinels were posted, who easily level
led them with their muskets. They are
now extinct in some of the islands, having
been extirpatsd by eagles. One would
think it Incredible than All eagle should ven
ture to attack so large an animal as the stag
of the great red deer The mode in which
the natives account for it is, that the eagles
plunge upon his head and fasten themselves
between the horns. The stag thus driven
to madness, rushes headiong over some pre-,
.cipce, when the eagle disengagcs himself
from his disabled victim, and devours hlm at
leisure. -Clarke's Life.

A report is in circulation. which we be-


icve originated in Philadelphia, that Mr..
Ovens establishment has been broken up
that Mr.. o. had gone to New Orleans. and
the Society have dispersed.-This report
we believe 10 be entirely untounded. The
"Gazette,' published at New-Harmony, is
regularly received at this office once week,
and no mention is made in it OF any such
"breaking up";; but from time to time ac-
counts are given of very prosperous and
Aourishfhg state of things in that community.

dating their accounts, there was balance

The Governor of New-York has, by a
proclamation, dated the 10Th March, offered
a reward of $1,000 for the discovery OF Nor
gan, if alive and if murdered, $4,000 for the
discovery of the offender or offenders, and a
free pardon to any accomplice or co-opera-
tor, who shall make a full discovery OF the
offender or offenders.

The brig Mcdusa. capt Aspclt, of Jersey.
while on her passage from La Guayra to
Liverpool, encountered thunder storm in
lat. 80 80, lon. 5S II, during which the cleo
trio fluid destroyed the magnetic power OF
the compasscs on board, two OF which were
on deck and two in the cabin. An optcian
has examined the compasses, and finds they
have entirely lost their attractive powers.

The pleasant Spring weather which we
have enjoyed fer few days past. has
brought with it an unusual hustle among the
business doing members of our mercantile
and Mechanical community. Our mechanics
have an unusual run of business. New hous-
es building and old ones to be repaired, have
put all hands in requisition, and the highest
wages are offered to industrious men. We
do not know when we have seen so many
brick dwellings "going up" in this place, as
at this time. We ask no better sign ofpros-
perity than this-wealth is the result OF in
dustry and economy. and our citizens are as
remarkable for both these traits OF charac-
ter, as any elsewhere. "By Industry sye
thriye." This is the motto OF the people
of Wilmington; and whilst others are spec
ulating in customary schemes of wealth, let
US stick BY trade. and trade will stick by us

Suiting tie aetion TO the woyd.-In a re-
cent trial for assault and battery in Pennsyl


vania, the counsel for the defendant asked
one of the witnesses. a stout. athletic man,
to describe to him the manner in which
the man was assaulted; when he immediate
ly took hold of the counsel by the collar and
gave him tremendous shaking, to the no
small amusement of the judges, spectators.
&c. who were convulsed with laughter.


Troubles in Canada-A Buffalo paper oi
the 10Th inst. says, "For several days past
there have been alarming reports in tircula-
tion of commotons in our neighboring prov
ince Of Upper Canada. a vast number OF
the inhabitants of the province will come
within the operation of the alien law. II
would appear that they are resolved not tc
snbmit to it; and It is reported that libert,
poles, on which were displayed the Ameri
can hag, have been raised in several places
an York. liberty pole was raised, and thu
american flag waved on it, within few
,ods OF the capitol. 1t was promptly pu
eeown by the Government party. A larg
1orce was then collected from the country
an, aMd the pole and flag were again raised.-
inese may be exaggerated reports; but VI
.aink @ there is something to make them GU
,rE@ ne who is great in small matters, is alway
small in great ones.

full articles.headline: GOVERNOR PENN.
full articles.article:
In 1899, Governor Penn, when in Pennsyl-
vania. was informed of some choice land, not
included in his former purchase of the lndi-
ans. He caused inquiry to be made of the
chiefs whether they would sell it to him.
They replied that they did not wish to part
,,;,h that land. as the bones of their fathers
and their mothers were lying there; but still.
to please their father Onas they would sell
some oft. For certain quantity of Eng
lish goods they agreed to sell him as much
land as one Of his young men coulo wax a
round in day; beginning at the grea' rly-
er Coaquanoc," now Kens'ngton, "ana END
,ng at the great river Just below halaPih

full articles.headline: WOOL CARDING.
full articles.article:
SeOHN BANCROFT, having removed from


~ Brandywine Bridge, to Providence Factc-
ry, Delaware Co. Pa, takes this means to In
form his friends and the public generally, that
he there continues the Cardng of Wool, for all
those who are pleased to favor him with their
custom; and that he hopes by strict attention and
nunctualjty,I 10 merit a continuance of pub
lie patronage He also takes this opportunity
to inform those to whose favor he was indebted
for work in this line, while at Brandywine Bridge,
that all wool left rhim to card, at John Torbers
Store, or at the soap Factory of Brainton 8. Ban
croft, wilmington, or at VIM. 'Cauley's Store,
Brandy vine, will be taken from thence once ev-
cry week, and, being carded, will be punctually
retuned the week following; hoping, by the a.
hove arrangement, and punctualy in the return
and GOOD performance of the work cenGded to
him, they may be induced to continue their fa-
YOURS.


4tb mo. S, 1897. 29-3m

full articles.headline: CIEANTMGS.
full articles.article:
In consequence Of the increased demand for
the American Quarterly Review, the publishers
have found it necessary to put to press second
edition of the first number OF that work, allho'
there were two thousand issued at first.


The amount of donations to the Philadelphia
Greek fund is Sl6,670.


The last cotton crop Of Tennessee is expected
TO fall short of tDo millions and h0t dollars, or
even three millions. Trade is very brisk at Nash
Vile.


Capt. keppell, in hia Journey from India.
says he killed brace of partridges in the
Garden of Eden.-Quere, were they not
birds ofParad,se?


Lord Norbury observing an officer dane
ing one evening with guineas as spur -rowels,
remarked, "that in addition to his other
property. he had got f.vo saineas 10 boot"


The ships John Adams and Lexington, and
schooner Grampus, arrived at Pensacola on
the 25th Feb.


Henry w. Dwight is reelected Represen-
tativc in Congress from Berkshire District,
Mass.


Mcssrs. Carey s. Lea are about to publish a
work, which is understood to be from the pen of
Alexander Everette, Esq. minister plenipotentia-
ry Of the United States, at Madrid, and which
bears the title


"Amerca, or General Survey of the Polite
al Situation of the several Powers of the West
ern Continent, with Conjcctures on their Future
Prospects, -Matre pulchra fila pulchrior by a
Citizen of the United States, author Of Europe,
&c."


We learn from the Democratic Press Of
March 27, that J. c. Gilleland. Esq. has been
associated with Mr.. Binns In the editorial
department of that paper.


In discussion which took place in the n
York Legislature, on the Chemung Canal
in 1916, the canal debt will have been paid
and leave an excess Of four million to the
State.

full articles.headline: ADVENT OF THE. MARTINS.
full articles.article:
These harbingers of spring, after having
without any outfit, performed the duties OF
their mission to South America, have sent
on special messengers to announce their re,
turn and to take possession OF their ola
quarters. The whole CROPS may be
soon expected. as their cDanf eon'iers never
precede the main body more than week.
The usual time of their return from their
southern residence, is about the 2oth OF
March, and when they come sooner II is
to announce great fruit year. Our Hor-
ticultural friends are therefore ADVISED to
prepare their brandy casks and cordial Jugs
in due time, as there can be no doubt o,
their having use for all they ever had' ano
more besides-JTar. Reh.

full articles.headline: For the Wiimingtonian.
full articles.article:
1MPROMPTU,
To young Lady on presenting me cake IN form


Of a heart.
And Rachel will you give your heart
To sad misfortune's wayward child
And with boon so precious part,
For one by sad a0liction spoiPdf
Say, shall take in my fond care,
The dearest pledge to mortals given,
And with affection place il near
Thy hapless friends, by sorrow riven'
Then give it hcre-yes, give it here,
And will ever fondly cherish,
With warm affection, one so dear,
Till every pulse of life shall perish.
And then thought how flecting time,
Would sudden pa its sceptre Ger,
And doom me to distant cline,
Where may never see thee more:
but yet, something told my heart,
'Twould cherish thee tho far apart.


BRANDYWINE MINSTREL.

We have received by an arrival at Philadelphia
from Monte Video, Bucnos Ayrcs papers from
Dec 10, to Jan. f, inclusive; but owing to their
not coming to hand until just as our paper was
going to press, we are compelled to defer max
ing extracts till next week.

full articles.article:
The Subscriber being about to change his bus
iness, hereby gives notice to all persons indebted

JOHN RICE.

full articles.headline: ATTENTION!
full articles.article:
The Commissioned Officers ofthe first brigade
Delaware Militia, are requested to attend at the
Red Lion Inn, on Saturday, the 14th inst. at 10
O'Clock in the forenoon, upon important business
relative TO the organization OF the Militia


WIN. COOCH, Major Gen.
hprl 9, 1897. 29-tm.

CO." now Bristol. The bargain being made,
a young Englishman, much accustomed to
travelling, was selected to lay cut the land.
His walk both astonished and mortified the
Indians. When they came for their pay,
the Governor perceived dissatifaction in
their countenances and asked the cause.


They replied that the young man had
cheated them.
"Ah, how can that be-" said William
Penn. "Was it not of your own choosing
that the ground should be measured in this
way!'


"True," replied the Indians. "but the
white brother made too big walk"
Some of Penn's commissioners became
one-that the Indians ought to stand to it,
and if not, they ought to be compelled.


"Comhelled" replied the Governor.


show are they to be compelled DON'T you


see that this points to murder I" Then turn
ing to the Indians with smiling counte-
nance he said to thcm-"Well, if you have


given too much land for the goods first a


egreed on, how much more will do?''


With this the Indians appeared much


pleased, and mentioned the number of yards


of cloth, and FISH hooks, with which they


would be satisfied. These wese given, then


the Indians shook hands with the Governor,


and retired smiling and happy. The Indl-


ans being gone, William Penn looked around


on his friends, and lifting his hands and eyes
exclaimed-"O what sweet and cheap
thing is charity Mention was made just
now Of comtciling these poor creatures to
;, stick to their bargain; that is in plain Eng
lish to fight and kill them-and all about a


little piece Of land J"


y This account is the substance of the story
:; as related in Wecms' life of William Penn
1t is so characteristic OF that remarkable
4 man, that there can be little doubt of its gen.
uincncss and authenticity.


). How happy it would have been for The
Z, early settlers of all the American colonies
n and how happy for the numerous tribes o
n aborigines, had all our ancestors possessed
d the pacific policy Of Governor Penn How


much anxiety and distress. and how man,


hundreds of lives would have been saved
,s And who can help wishing that the peopl
IS of Georgia, at the present time, might b.
e blessed with william Penn, fer their Gov
e crnor! In that case, how easy it would b
q to settle all difficulties with the Greek Indi
y ans.-Friend Of Peace.

full articles.headline: Female Bible Society.
full articles.article:
The inhabitants of this Borough are respect
fully invited to attend the annual meeting of the
Female Bible Society, on Thursday evening the
18th inst. at O'Clock, at the .4cademy, where
an appropriate address will be delivered by the
Rev. Mr.. COSNELLY.

Commercial AQvertlsef,) WIKI VAC Si6hs Va
letters dated on the goth. which announce
the severe and dangerous situation OF Lord
Liverpool. On the 18th, His Lordship had
a severe attack Of the palsy and apoplexy,
from which he was not expected to recover.
Mr.. Canning continued i'll at the last advices
from London.-The illness Of those distin-
guished and leading men, had caused great
panic in the Stock Market, and the funds
had fallen two per cent. One of the let
ters says, "You know the great corn question
was to be brought forward on the 26th,-
what will be done now we cannot say; but
the subject will most probably be further
postponed until some change takes place in
the situation of Lord Liverpool and Mr..
Canning"


The ship Chancellor, Captain Baker, with
provisions for the Greeks, sailed from New
York on Monday morning last, having been
thoroughly repaired. Her cargo was not
damaged in the gale which caused her to
return to poEs.


The value of American Manufactured
Cotton Goods sold at Philadelphia in sim
tle year, it is stated, varies but little from
FOUR MILLIONS OF DOLLARS, and
is rapidly increasing, whereas in the years
1SO4-5-6, the whole amount sold in the city
was only Sl7,67o!


Destruction of Insects.-As the season OF
vegetation approaches, remark upon the
application of tobacco water in the destruc-
tion OF insects may not be amiss. In the pro-
cess Of preparing tobacco for use, liquid is
finally expressed from it, which is very
cheap, and highly destructive to animal life
This mixed with three to five parts water,
is found to be an eilectual remedy, for the
aphies, caterpillars, and similar insects
which infcst fruit trees.


MtcNigeneer, Ahoy!


: You give US long yarn in tile paper to
, day, about Christmas Pie made by Mrs
Tagg, OF .hgg. or Hagg, at the king's Arm


Inn, that contained a turkey and a couple Q


rabbits, and few more such like trifles.-
+ Why, / can tell you about Christmas Pi
r that would have swalled up one hundred c
, Mrs. Hagg's. Itwas once, when black Jacl
!, lay in Hampton Roads with old Ironsides-
. no, let me sce-I ant sure but it was tn
{ United States--Howsomdev as Christina
was at hand, the crew axed old Jack ifthc,
' might make PIE, and when he said yes
/ every man put in, sent up the long boat ant


tender to Norfolk, and there bought a tur


key for every man in the ship, which wa
| hard upon 5o0.--Well. these 500 turkeys
besides sundry bushels of potatoes and -four
e and other condiments, as our Doctor calle'
{ them, was all made into Christmas Pie
in the ships great boiler. Now, here wa
r pie worth talking about-so don't give u
a any more jaw about Mrs. Hagg's brace q
;. rabbits and a goose.


Yours to command.


BOB SPRITSAIL.
Washington Nary Yard, March 81.

Lion Tavern, New Castle County, Del, and Mr.

ANFCDOTE OF COLUMBUS.


Deter MARTYR. In his very curious account OF
coumbus' vevages, tells us that on his land-
,,g an the Island Of Jamaica. he immediate
im"peaus.d mp mass to be said on account ot the
.s,fe landing of himself and followers, and
.,., during the performance of that sacred !
my,,ery, an old Carib, eighty years OF age.
a,tended by several Of his countrymen, OBJ
.crved the service with great attention. At |
,.r;t was over, the old man approached Co.
lmbus with basket OF fruit IN his hand,
which he in very courteous manner pre-
sented to him, and by means OF au interpre-
ter thus addressed him:
ave have been told, that you have in a
verv powerful and surprising manner ran o.
YER several countries which were before un-
knowa to you,' and that you have filled the
inhabitants with fear and amazement.-----
Wherefore exhort and desire you to re-
member that the souls Of men when they arc
separated from :helr bodies have ivy" pas
sages; the one hurrd and dark, prepared
for those who have been troublesome and
inimicsl to the human race; the other,
rlcasant and delightful one, appointed for





n the peace and quiet of mankind. There
fore YOU will do no hurt to any one, II you
b-ar in mind that you are mortal and that
every one will be rewarded or punished in
, future state, according to his actions in the
present one"
Columbus. by the interpreter, answered
,heold man. "that what he had told respect
fnr the passage Of the souls after the death
Of the body, had been long known to him
and his countrymen, and that he was much
SURPRISED those notions prevailed among
them. who seemed to be living in quite a
state a. nature. That he (Columbus) and
his followers, were sent by the King and
Oueen ofSpain, to discover all those parts
If the world that had hitherto been unknown,
that they might civilize the cannibals and
other wild men that lived in those countries,
and intlict proper punishment upon them,
and that they might defend and honor those
nersons who were virtuous and innocent :
and that therefore neither himself nor any
other Carb, who had no intention Of hurting
them. had the least reason to fear any vio-
lcncc and that they would avepge any inju-
~ that should be offered to him or any other
worthy persons of the island, by any Of their
neighbors."


The old man was 50 pleased with the
sn.ech and the manner of Columbus, that
though he was extremely old, he offered tc
follow Columbus, and would have done so
had not his wife and children prevented him
The old man appeared much surprised tl
understand how man of Columbus dignlt!
and appearance should be under the controu
of another person, and became much moro
astonished when the interpreter explained
20 him the honor, the pomp and wealth. o
sc nnI IA.
extent Of the country and the greatness ant
beauty of the things over which they reign
ed. lie became pensive, melancholy, and il
Aood Of tears asked the interpreter repeat
cdly. whether it were the heavens or eartl
which had produced men so superior 4
themselves as Columbus and his followers


The Floridds.--Varous accounts hav
been Given fthe Floridas. The first dis
ceyerers of the coast described it as terres
tial paradise; and it still retains tho name c
the iscountry of flowers" which these marin
ers first gave it, in their surprize at the bea
" of its aspect when they landed. MI
Flint in his RecoliectionS, describes 1t as pri


cipally composed of pine barrens, intersect
ed by unwholesome meadows on the bank
of the rivers A traveller lately returnc
from Florida says it is the most fertile cour
try he ever found, the lands producing .fo'
~ bushels Of frogs TO the gore, and alf'gd
tors enough TO fence them.


Joe Daviess County.-This is without cs
ceptiOn the most ludicrous honor ever cor
ferred by a legislature upon the memory
any individual; but true it is that the legl


lature of Illinois a, its last session passed a
act establishing Jo Daviess County, and o


dered "that 1--WE quote the language OF It


act) to perpetuate the memory OF Col. j


seph Hamilton Daviess, who fell in the ba


tie of Tippecanoe, gallantly charging upc


the enemy at the head Of his corps, the sa


county shall be called 10 Daviess." TT


legislature that passed such a law must il


deed have been Of most primitive order.

full articles.headline: FROM CANTON.
full articles.article:
The ship Maria, arrived at New York, on
Friday night last, from Canton, sailed 2oth
December. We learn by her, that III con-
sequence of the low prices of teas in China
and the bad accounts OF the American marx
ct being received there. the Hong mer-
chants had recommended their friends TO
sell their Teas in the interior, rather than
forward them to Canton; the consequence
has oeen the supply there was so very small
that the ships have all been detained much
longer than usual Before the Maria sailed,
subsequent accounts had been received IRON
this country, Of good prospects for the spring
trade, which caused very material advance


in the prices of Teas.--OlorainS ChFon'efe

ship Octavia, arrived at Boston, on Saturday
last, from Liverpool, whense she sailed on

Snare for taking The Red Deer IL the He
brides.--A wall or rampant OF stone was e
rec.ed along the side of a mountain, thanking
a considerable part near its basis; at either
extremity pit was formed concealed by a
circumference Of the same stones which
formed the rampant. In this pit the hunter
stationed himself with his gun. A number
of people were then employed to alarm the
deer, who instantly taking to the mountain
and meeting with the wall, ran along the
side of it till they came TO the pit in which
the sentinels were posted, who easily level
led them with their muskets. They are
now extinct in some of the islands, having
been extirpatsd by eagles. One would
think it Incredible than All eagle should ven
ture to attack so large an animal as the stag
of the great red deer The mode in which
the natives account for it is, that the eagles
plunge upon his head and fasten themselves
between the horns. The stag thus driven
to madness, rushes headiong over some pre-,
.cipce, when the eagle disengagcs himself
from his disabled victim, and devours hlm at
leisure. -Clarke's Life.

A report is in circulation. which we be-


icve originated in Philadelphia, that Mr..
Ovens establishment has been broken up
that Mr.. o. had gone to New Orleans. and
the Society have dispersed.-This report
we believe 10 be entirely untounded. The
"Gazette,' published at New-Harmony, is
regularly received at this office once week,
and no mention is made in it OF any such
"breaking up";; but from time to time ac-
counts are given of very prosperous and
Aourishfhg state of things in that community.

bQcHeI0TS DdH.-l nc Managers oI Tue
Ball had final meeting on Saturday even
ing, to settle their accounts; exchange con-
dolence on their state Of single wretched-
ness; express hopes of the future, and take
parting glass of Champagne. On hqui-
dating their accounts, there was balance
in favor of the Greeks OF four hundred and
sin dollars. Well done.


.Neah's Enquirer.


The Governor of New-York has, by a
proclamation, dated the 10Th March, offered
a reward of $1,000 for the discovery OF Nor
gan, if alive and if murdered, $4,000 for the
discovery of the offender or offenders, and a
free pardon to any accomplice or co-opera-
tor, who shall make a full discovery OF the
offender or offenders.


The Painsvillc (Ohio) Telegraph says, that at
the late term Of the Court of Common Pleas OF
Portage county, COL George Darfow, was found
guilty of countcrfeiting, and sentenced TO inc
Pententiary for five ycars.--'i,he Quarterly Re
viewers have laughed, not unjustly, at our fond
ness for military titles, and made themselves
merry with the idea that our stages are driven
and our tavcrns are kept by Generals and Colo
nels. They may now add, that our pcnltcnua-
ries arc not without their proportion OF titled
convlcts.

The brig Mcdusa. capt Aspclt, of Jersey.
while on her passage from La Guayra to
Liverpool, encountered thunder storm in
lat. 80 80, lon. 5S II, during which the cleo
trio fluid destroyed the magnetic power OF
the compasscs on board, two OF which were
on deck and two in the cabin. An optcian
has examined the compasses, and finds they
have entirely lost their attractive powers.

The pleasant Spring weather which we
have enjoyed fer few days past. has
brought with it an unusual hustle among the
business doing members of our mercantile
and Mechanical community. Our mechanics
have an unusual run of business. New hous-
es building and old ones to be repaired, have
put all hands in requisition, and the highest
wages are offered to industrious men. We
do not know when we have seen so many
brick dwellings "going up" in this place, as
at this time. We ask no better sign ofpros-
perity than this-wealth is the result OF in
dustry and economy. and our citizens are as
remarkable for both these traits OF charac-
ter, as any elsewhere. "By Industry sye
thriye." This is the motto OF the people
of Wilmington; and whilst others are spec
ulating in customary schemes of wealth, let
US stick BY trade. and trade will stick by us

The value of American Manufactured

tle year, it is stated, varies but little from
FOUR MILLIONS OF DOLLARS, and
is rapidly increasing, whereas in the years
1804-5-6, the whole amount sold in the city
was only Sl7,670!

The ship Chancellor, Captain Baker, with
provisions for the Greeks, sailed from New
York on Monday morning last. having been
thoroughly repaired. Her cargo was not
damaged in the gale which caused her to
return to poEt.

Suiting tie aetion TO the woyd.-In a re-
cent trial for assault and battery in Pennsyl


vania, the counsel for the defendant asked
one of the witnesses. a stout. athletic man,
to describe to him the manner in which
the man was assaulted; when he immediate
ly took hold of the counsel by the collar and
gave him tremendous shaking, to the no
small amusement of the judges, spectators.
&c. who were convulsed with laughter.


Troubles in Canada-A Buffalo paper oi
the 10Th inst. says, "For several days past
there have been alarming reports in tircula-
tion of commotons in our neighboring prov
ince Of Upper Canada. a vast number OF
the inhabitants of the province will come
within the operation of the alien law. II
would appear that they are resolved not tc
snbmit to it; and It is reported that libert,
poles, on which were displayed the Ameri
can hag, have been raised in several places
an York. liberty pole was raised, and thu
american flag waved on it, within few
,ods OF the capitol. 1t was promptly pu
eeown by the Government party. A larg
1orce was then collected from the country
an, aMd the pole and flag were again raised.-
